bibl.title: Thomas Allen v. John H. McGraw. Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: In the District Court of the Third Judicial District of Washington Territory holding Terms at Seattle in King County.
In the Matter of the application of Thos. Allen for a writ of Habeas Corpus.

To the Honorable C. H. Hanford Judge of the aboce Court. Your petitioner herein Thos. Allen represents to your Honor that he is restrained of his liberty at the County Jail of King County in the City of Seattle aforesaid by me J. H. McGraw the Sheriff of said King County.

That the cause & pretense of said restraint is a certain committment is and by our H. F. Jones who was at the time of issuing the same in legally elected qualified & acting Justice of the Peace of said City of Seattle, held by said J. H. McGraw as Sheriff aforesaid. A true copy of the siad Committment is hereto at=
attached herein referred to made a fact hereof and Marked Exhibit "A"

And your petitoner herein for then alleges that said restraint is illegal and that said committment has County ceased to be any force & effect for the reason that it was issued long before the first day of this last term of this Court at which a Grand Jury was in session and that the attention of said Grand Jury was called the so the charge agaisnt this petitioner & that no action was taken whatever by said Grand Jury on said Charge & that said Grand Jury and Court adjurned long since.
Wherefrom your petitioner pray that this your Honor do grant & cause to
be assined a Writ of Habeas corpus to the said third & have sai your petitioner brought before your Honor that he may be dealt with according to law Thos Allen by E. C. Million his atty.

Territory of Washington County of King ss E. C. Williams being first duly sworn deposes & says that he is attorney for petitioner & that the matters + facts setforth in the forgoing Petition and then as he verily believes E. C. Million
Subscribed & sworn to before me this 18th day of April 1889 C. H. Hanford Judge
